James, Jesusâ€™ brother wrote about them (and about Trump/MAGA and Christian fundamentalists) that â€œfaith without works is dead.â€ We see these people who proclaim their faith but their works donâ€™t exist so I call them the phony faith people. Iâ€™m now 88, white retired with grandma here in Texas. When I was fresh out of the Marines in 1962 I went to the 1st Baptist Church here in Fort Worth. After a couple of months the preacher said to me â€œwow, with your voice you could make a lot of money preaching on the radio/tv.â€ I was so turned off by that that I quit that church. But hereâ€™s the fun, fun part. I did go to the radio stations around Dallas/Fort Worth to get a job on the air. I had no experience so I had to put in time in little Texas towns radio stations (think KMOO in Mineola, Texas). But after a few years I hit the big time in my hometown Fort Worth on WBAP (a 50,000 kw blaster) country gold radio. Sad, but true. I don't know whether to laugh or cry.   My husband is a pastor.  We do all that we can to serve our community. We have a Free Market for the poor. We do free meals on Wednesdays and some Sunday evenings (most of which we pay for ourselves). My husband receives less than half the salary of the pastor before him. I clean the church for free. Our family is the Worship Team. The last Worship Team was paid $7K per year to sing (I never understood that). We do that for free, etc. We do not use the parsonage, but the church rents it out to pay my husband's salary.   We pray with our people when they are sick or in trouble. We visit them in the hospital. We take them food if they need it. We don't ask for anything for ourselves.  If the churches are taxed, then these horrible mega churches, who can afford it, will continue to grow and buy themselves gifts...while little churches like ours...will be put out of business. Sad, but true.   The church was never intended for this. If people actually read their Bibles, they would clearly see the heresy in these horrible wolves. God clearly tells us that the LOVE of money is the root of ALL evil. It sickens me that people take advantage of others who truly need to be loved, cared for, prayed for, and helped.   You will know them by their fruits.

Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, has proposed to create a new civilian military force that he would control, instead of the federal government. He calls it the *Florida State Guard* and says it would help with state emergencies, such as hurricanes and pandemics. He wants the state legislature to give him $3.5 million to train and equip 200 volunteers for this force .  However, some critics have accused DeSantis of having authoritarian motives and creating his own private army. They fear that he could use the state guard for political purposes, such as interfering with elections or opposing federal policies. DeSantis has also proposed to create a special police force to investigate election fraud, which has alarmed voting rights advocates.  The Florida State Guard would be separate from the Florida National Guard, which is jointly funded by the state and the federal government and can be deployed by either authority. Florida had a state guard during World War II, but it was disbanded in 1947 . If DeSantis succeeds in reestablishing it, Florida would join 22 other states that have active state guards .

I left the Episcopal Church at the tender age of twelve, because during confirmation class, I challenged the theory that those who don't consciously accept Jesus Christ as their savior won't go to heaven, despite leading a perfectly "Christian" life. However; since then my life has been studded with little miracles, including one where this very guy was blathering about some lady with an inflamed hipjoint and in constant pain (which I was, and had gone into the bedroom to turn the TV off) so I flopped down to watch something I never had before, a TV Evangelist. My hip was in its usual painful state, and as I lay there prepared to be amused, the whole hip area exploded in heat, it subsided, and has never hurt since, which it had done since the birth of my son some twelve years earlier. I have to say, this world is filled with absurdity, and if several other events had not occurred to me over the years, I'd at least be an agnostic, if not an atheist. But they have, so I'm not. I have concluded that there is "magic", and I enjoy this quasi-religious existence I lead, despite all of the nonsense, sleaze, and bravado of this often disreputable side of the story.

Happy day off everyone .... In celebration of first-generation Americans and our history as a nation of immigrants, we should change the holiday to Yogi Berra Day. Everyone loves Yogi. He was a first-generation American, so a holiday named after him could both serve to celebrate our heritage as a nation of immigrants, while still being something that Italian Americans could embrace. When it comes to Yogi, there is something for everyone. He served in the Navy during World War II; he was a family man and a good person. He was also very inclusive as he welcomed African American players after the color line was broken and he joined an organization dedicated to ending homophobia long before that cause was more broadly embraced. He was a successful businessman; certainly not a buffoon or a yahoo as he liked to pretend. He was funny and didn't take himself too seriously. He was not a tall man but a towering figure in sports who won 3 MVP awards and was part of numerous championships earning 10 world series rings: one for every finger. The thing is the burden of proof is one the one making the claim. You cannot disprove that there is a little black teapot orbiting mars, therefore there is a little black teapot orbiting mars does not follow. We have no reason to think sending your money to a conman will get you more money in return, it's not up to us to "prove" that is the case.  That being said I imagine it would be quite easy to compare the amount of people who have "seeded" money with these conmen and the amount they've lost/gained on average, with a completely random control group. I would guess this analysis would show people who seed lose as much as they spend seeding on average, with a consistent number of outliers in both groups gaining a lot, and many more people losing a lot from the scammed group due to selection bias (desperate people who are on the brink of losing everything tend to buy into these scams more often than financially stable people, after all).
